s.gd: ’S beag a bha dh’fhios aca gur e am bruadraiche a bhuannaicheadh aig a’ cheann thall.
s.en: Little did they know that it is the dreamer who would win at the end of the day.

s.gd: Tha mi sgrìobhadh seo a-nochd anns an Eiphit.
s.en: I am writing this tonight in Egypt.

s.gd: (Chan fhaic duin’e ach mi-fhìn.)
s.en: (Nobody will see it but myself.)

s.gd: Nuair sheallas mi mach air an uinneig chì mi biorramaidean na Pharaohs, ’s chì mi a’ ghrian aca a’ dol fodha.
s.en: When I look out of the window, I see the Pharaoh’s pyramids, and I see their sun going down.

s.gd: Tha mi smaoineachadh air mo bhràithrean.
s.en: I am thinking about my brothers.

s.gd: O, bha iad toilichte gu leòr mo mharbhadh, no mo shadail anns an t-sloc.
s.en: Oh, they were happy enough killing me, or dumping me in the pit.

s.gd: Airson a’ chòta iomadhathach a bh’agam.
s.en: For the multi-coloured coat that I had.

s.gd: Cha do thuig iad mi a-riamh — ’s cha thuig iad dè ’s ciall don chòta sin.
s.en: They never understood me – and they will not understand what that coat meant.

s.gd: Tha còta coltach ris orm an-dràsda fhèin.
s.en: I have a similar coat on just now.

s.gd: Ged dh’fheuch iad ri mo mharbhadh cha deach ac’ air ’s cha tèid leotha a chaoidh.
s.en: Even though they tried to kill me, they did not success and they will never succeed.

s.gd: Sin an rud nach eil iad a’ tuigsinn.
s.en: That is the thing that they do not understand.

s.gd: Cha do dh’aithnich iad mi an toiseach nuair thàinig iad ach dh’aithnich mis’ iadsan.
s.en: They did not recognise me at first when they came but I recognised them.

s.gd: Is bha sin ceart gu leòr.
s.en: And that was right enough.

s.gd: Oir cha do dh’aithnich iad mi a-riamh.
s.en: Because they had never recognised me.

s.gd: Tha cuimhn’ agam a’ mhadainn a thubhairt mi riutha gun dèanadh iad ùmhlachd dhomh.
s.en: I remember the morning I said to them that they would pay attention to me.

s.gd: B’ ann aig àm an lòn-maidne a bh’ann ’s bha mi air èirigh às mo leabaidh, làn dòchais is aoibhneis.
s.en: It was at the time of the breakfast and I had gotten up out of my bed, full of hope and joy.

s.gd: Dh’innis mi dhaibh mu dheidhinn mo bhruadair, ach cha smaoinicheadh iadsan air càil ach airgead.
s.en: I told them about my dream, but they would only think about money.

s.gd: Mise na mo chòta iomadhathach ’s iadsan nan còtaichean truagh làitheil.
s.en: Me in my multi-coloured coat and them in their sad everyday coats.

s.gd: Dè chiall a bh’acasan?
s.en: What sense did they have?

s.gd: ’S a-nis tha mi na mo mhaor os cionn na h-Eiphit — am bruadraiche!
s.en: And now I am a middle-ranked official over Egypt – the dreamer!

s.gd: O, tha deagh fhios agam gun dèanadh iad an aon rud a-rithist, nam faigheadh iad an cothrom.
s.en: Oh, I know well that the would do the same thing again, if they would get the chance.

s.gd: Dh’ionnsaich mi mòran anns an t-sloc.
s.en: I had learned a lot in the pit.

s.gd: Choinnich mi am bàs an latha ud, ’s choinnich mi ’n fharmad.
s.en: I had met death that day, and I had met jealousy.

s.gd: Bha mo chòta iomadhathach làn fala.
s.en: My multicoloured coat was full of blood.

s.gd: Dh’èirich biasd às an dorchadas ceart gu leòr ach tha fhios agam a-nis gu bheil a’ bhiasd ud ann.
s.en: A beast rose out of the darkness right enough but I know now that that beast is there.

s.gd: Sin bu choireach nach robh eagal orm anns a’ phrìosan.
s.en: That is why I was not afraid in the prison.

s.gd: Cha bhàsaich duine dà uair.
s.en: No man dies twice.

s.gd: Gach oidhche bithidh mi sgrìobhadh nam bruadairean a bhios a’ tighinn nam inntinn.
s.en: Every night I will be writing the dreams that will be coming in my mind.

s.gd: Tha fhios agam de thachras anns an Eiphit cuideachd.
s.en: I know what will happen in Egypt as well.

s.gd: Thig Pharaoh ùr is tachraidh iomadh droch rud.
s.en: A new Pharaoh will come many bad things will occur.

s.gd: Ach chì mi cuideachd gum bi sinn saor.
s.en: But I will see too that we will be free.

s.gd: Chan e gun còrd mo bhruadairean ri daoine.
s.en: It is not that my dreams please people.

s.gd: Tha cuimhn’ agam nuair dh’innis mi don rìgh mu dheidhinn na goirt.
s.en: I remember when I told the king about the famine.

s.gd: Chunnaic mi an lasair na shùilean ceart gu leòr: dh’fhaodadh e bhith air cur às dhomh ’n uairsin: tha bith aca dhomh airson mo bhruadairean.
s.en: I saw the flame in his eyes right enough: he might have got rid of me then: they hated me from my dreams.

s.gd: Ach feumaidh cuideigin an fhìrinn innse.
s.en: But somebody must tell the truth.

s.gd: Is nach robh mo bhruadar ceart?
s.en: And was not my dream correct?

s.gd: Rinn iad ùmhlachd dhomh mar dh’innis mi dhaibh.
s.en: Thy heeded me as I told them.

s.gd: ’S a-nis tha mi an seo nam fhear-riaghlaidh, a’ làimhseachadh airgid — mise, am bruadraiche!
s.en: And now I am here a governor, handling money – me, the dreamer!

s.gd: Ruithidh iad às mo dhèidh cho fad ’s a bhios cumhachd agam.
s.en: They will run after me as long as I have power.

s.gd: Ach nuair thrèigeas an cumhachd?
s.en: But when will the power forsake me?

s.gd: Dè thachras an uairsin?
s.en: What will happen then?

s.gd: Ruithidh iad an dèidh cuideigin eile, mo bhràithrean, ach aon, Beniàmin.
s.en: They will run after somebody else, my brothers, apart from one, Benjamin.

s.gd: Cha dèan esan brath orm.
s.en: He will not betray me.

s.gd: Feumaidh mi creideas a chur an sin co-dhiù.
s.en: I must put credit there anyway.

s.gd: Nuair sheallas mi mach air an uinneig chì mi na biorramaidean.
s.en: When I look out of the window I see the pyramids.

s.gd: Tha iad aosd.
s.en: They are ancient.

s.gd: ’S tha iad mòr.
s.en: And they are big.

s.gd: Tha diathan eile anns an rìoghachd seo.
s.en: There are other gods in this kingdom.

s.gd: Tha i làn de nathraichean, barrachd na bh’anns a’ ghàrradh mhòr làn cùbhraidheachd.
s.en: It is full of snakes, more than there were in the big garden full of gragrance.

s.gd: Tha nathraichean anns gath àit.
s.en: There are snakes in every place.

s.gd: Sin a dh’ ionnsaich mi bho mo bhràithrean.
s.en: That is what I learned from my brothers.

s.gd: Mura bithinn air ionnsachadh cha bhithinn an seo an-diugh.
s.en: If I had not learned it, I would not be here today.

s.gd: ’Se iadsan a thug dhomh an cumhachd — ged nach do thuig iad e.
s.en: It is them who have me the power – even though they didn’t understand it.

s.gd: Shàbhail iad mi-fhìn ’s iad-fhèin leis an olc.
s.en: They rescued myself and themselves with the evil.

s.gd: Chan eil mi a’ tuigsinn sin.
s.en: I don’t understand that.

s.gd: Dh’ionnsaich mi cànan ùr’s shàbhail mi mo dhaoine leatha.
s.en: I learned a new language and I saved my people with it.

s.gd: Rinn mi gall dhìom fhìn air an son.
s.en: I make a foreigner of myself for them.

s.gd: ’S thug mi dhaibh biadh gallda ’s tha iad riaraicht.
s.en: And I brought them foreign food and they are satisfied.

s.gd: Tha adhbhar air choreigin air cùl sin, ged nach eil mi ga thuigsinn.
s.en: There is some kind of cause behind this, even if I do not understand it.

s.gd: Tha e toirt gàireachdainn orm.
s.en: It nakes me laugh.

s.gd: Bha iad cho neochiontach mu dheidhinn an airgid nam beachd fhèin: ach mhill iad mi air a shon.
s.en: They were so innocent bout the money in my own opinion: but they destroyed me for it.

s.gd: ’S chan fhac iad sin.
s.en: And they did not see that.

s.gd: ’S aig a’ cheann thall, ’se mis’ a rinn an t-airgead ’s cha b’e iadsan.
s.en: And at the end of the day, it is me that made the money and it was not them.

s.gd: Mise — am bruadraiche — a fhuair an cumhachd, gu seallainn dhaibh gun dèanainn sin cuideachd.
s.en: Me – the dreamer – who got the power, that I would show them that I would do that too.

s.gd: Is mura bitheadh iadsan, cha robh mi air sin a dhèanamh.
s.en: And if they would not be, I would not have done that.

s.gd: Eil iad a’ tuigsinn sin?
s.en: Do they understand that?

s.gd: Tha iad a’ dèanamh adhradh dhomh airson gu bheil an t-airgead agam, ach cha dèanadh iad adhradh dhomh nuair bha an còta iomadhathach agam.
s.en: They are praying for me to have money, but they would not pray for me when I had the multi-coloured coat.

s.gd: Chan fhaic iad sin nas motha.
s.en: They don’t see that any more.

s.gd: O, well.
s.en: Oh, well.

s.gd: Tha ’n oidhche a’ tuiteam ’s a’ ghrian a’ dol sìos air na biorramaidean, mar thèid a’ ghrian sìos air m’airgead-sa ’s air an airgead-san.
s.en: The night is falling and the sun is going down on the pyramids, as the sun will come down on my money and on their money.

s.gd: Bidh cuimhn’ aig daoine orm airson a’ chòta iomadhathach ’s airson mo bhruadairean, is chan ann airson mo chumhachd.
s.en: Men will remember me for the multi-coloured coat and for my dreams, and not for my power.

s.gd: Bu chòir dhaibh sin fhaicinn.
s.en: They should see that.

s.gd: Bu chaomh leam mòran a sgrìobhadh mu dheidhinn na h-Eiphit ach ’sann a tha mi sgrìobhadh mu dheidhinn mo bhràithrean ’s mo dhachaigh fhìn ged thachair iad rium.
s.en: I would like to write a lot about Egypt but I am writing about my brothers and my own home even though they happened upon me.

s.gd: Tha sin neònach, nach eil?
s.en: That is strange, is it not?

s.gd: Is chan aithne dhomh sgrìobhadh gu domhainn ann an chuain na h-Eiphit.
s.en: And I don’t know how to write deeply in the oceans of Egypt.

s.gd: Tha sin èibhinn cuideachd.
s.en: That is funny too.

s.gd: Tha h-uile càil cho èibhinn ’s gur ann a tha mi smaoineachadh: Chan eil rian nach deach mo thaghadh airson adhbhar iongantach air choreigin.
s.en: Everything is so funny that I am thinking: There is nothing that I was not chosen for some surprising reason or other.

s.gd: ’S tha sin èibhinn cuideachd.
s.en: And that is funny as well.
